dataset.shortName: Zooplankton Biomass (Organic Carbon) - Spring Annual Averages
dataset.title: Annual zooplankton biomass calculated from zooplankton counts of samples from the Ohman region, CalCOFI lines 80 to 93, stations from shore to station 70. Original data from the zooplankton dataspace.

creator.organizationName: California Current Ecosystem Long-Term Ecological Research Program

intellectualRights.para: Citation acknowledgement: Data from the California Current Ecosystem LTER data repository were supported by funding sources

section.title: abstract
section.para: Annual zooplankton biomass from enumeration of plankton counts that are converted to organic carbon biomass using length-carbon relationship. Spring cruises (usually April, range: March–May) were the focus because they provided the best interannual coverage, attention to a single season permitted address of interannual rather than seasonal variability, and because this is an important time period of fish spawning. Samples are archived in the Pelagic Invertebrates Collection of the Scripps Institution of Oceanography. Ref: Lavaniegos and Ohman (2007).

section.title: methods
section.para:
All organisms were enumerated from the plankton samples and converted to organic carbon biomass using length–carbon relationships, then aggregated into 19 major taxa. Large organisms (>25 mm total length) were counted from each entire sample, identified, and sized. These organisms were removed from the samples prior to pooling. A volume of each sample corresponding to 50 m3 of seawater filtered was then removed and combined into a pooled sample for each cruise (Rebstock, 2001). One quarter of each pooled sample was counted. In nonpooled samples, 1/8 was analyzed. All zooplankton were identified to the lowest taxonomic level practical for our expertise (over 400 taxa; usually species) and measured to the nearest mm, then aggregated into 19 (or fewer) major holoplankton taxa for analysis present purposes.
Spring annual averages are from samples usually taken in April (range: February–May). sampling was carried out only every third year in the late 1960s to early-mid 1970s. The net tows were double oblique. Over time, the net tows changed from a CalCOFI ring net to 140m, with 1m net mouth diameter and 0.55 mm net mesh (C1s; 1951-1968) to a CalCOFI ring net to 210m depth with 1m net mouth diameter and 0.505 mm net mesh (C1n; 1969-1977), to a CalCOFI bongo to 210m depth with 0.71 net mouth diameter and 0.505 mm net mesh (CB; 1977- present; see Ohman and Smith 1995). Sampling characteristics (see code controlled vocabulary for zooplankton sampling characteristics: http://oceaninformatics.ucsd.edu/datazoo/resources/controlledvocabularies?action=set&id=194).The sample preservative is sodium tetraborate-buffered formaldehyde.
Abundances within size classes were converted to organic carbon biomass by applying carbon–length regressions or a combination of dry mass–length regressions and carbon percentage from the literature. Since the zooplankton categories analyzed are mixtures of species, we estimated carbon–length relationships using values of carbon content from diverse species, giving preference to those inhabiting the North Pacific.

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: Sampling takes place west of California. Sampling arrangements include use of the CalCOFI fixed grid of stations located within the Southern California Bight along offshore transects from San Diego to Point Conception and use of moving stations centered on drifters or drogues.

section.title: Geographic Description
section.para: Pacific Ocean Southern California Bight (SCB) and region offshore. Ohman Region; CalCOFI lines 80-93, stations from shore to offshore station 70, inclusive.

project.title: California Current Ecosystem Long-Term Ecological Research Program

abstract.para: The California Current Ecosystem program is a member site of the Long-Term Ecological Research program, a network of sites investigating diverse biomes. A team of researchers is investigating nonlinear transitions in the California Current coastal pelagic ecosystem, with particular attention to long-term forcing by a secular warming trend, the Pacific Decadal Oscillation, and El Nino in altering the structure and dynamics of the pelagic ecosystem. The California Current System is a coastal upwelling biome, as found along the eastern margins of all major ocean basins. These are among the most productive ecosystems in the world ocean. The California Current sustains active fisheries for a variety of finfish and marine invertebrates, modulates weather patterns and the hydrologic cycle of much of the western United States, and plays a vital role in the economy of myriad coastal communities.

attribute.attributeDefinition: biological material from living or recently living plants and animals

methodStep.description: [dataAnalysis]: calculationType { calculated }; calculationTypeDetail { derived }; calculationInterval { year }
